results.description: The Old Farmer’s Almanac” 224th edition– Is it accurate and relevant? Why?    “The Old Farmer’s Almanac”, has been in continuous publication since its first edition in 1792 by Robert B. Thomas and has been expanded beyond its original forecasts for Boston and the New England states to all of the United States.   Its forecasts have been relied on by farmers, businesses, and governments for planning and preparing for weather conditions from the time of George Washington to the present day.  And the Almanac boasts of an average 80% accuracy in its forecasts.   But, how actually accurate is it?  How are its forecasts determined? Do its publishers rely only on prior weather history, or a secret formula derived by its first publisher R. Thomas,  or are modern meteorological methods employed? In the Almanac the contiguous states are grouped into 16 distinct weather areas and the forecasts are detailed for each area. (Alaska and Hawaii are in separate areas.) and current US Government weather studies are grouped by 30 year statistical averages, with the[masked] tabulations being the most recent.   After analyzing the Almanac’s weather forecasts for this last year their overall accuracy rate was 96.3% for the 18 regions.   Our speaker Bill Mirabello will discuss The Almanac at the SIGS October meeting. Bill has always been interested in the weather, from dreading the snow he would shovel each winter to how soon he could plant his gardens every Spring.   Side note: For the NYC area the first frost date is Nov 7th and the last Spring frost is April 3rd.   Bill will discuss weather activity, what influences it – do sun spots or heavenly bodies affect the weather, Weather patterns – short term and long term, and how modern meteorologists study the weather; its trends and events.     Bill earned his degree in geology in 1972, is a member of the AIPG, and first learned about weather at the knee of his father who had a career as a meteorologist/ on-air broadcaster for the US Weather Service after serving as a meteorologist in the US Navy.
results.name: October Meeting of Staten Island Geological Society Inc.

_______________________

Antonio “Junior” Cervila is an internationally known performer, choreographer and instructor. He is recognized for his creative tango stylings, his intricate footwork, as well as his dance versatility. Junior has been choreographic assistant to tango legend, Juan Carlos Copes, and his performances have been seen worldwide on Argentinian television, on stage (Broadway’s “Tango Argentino”), on tour (most notably with Julio Iglesias) and on screen (“Tango”, nominated for an Academy Award for best foreign film, 1999). Junior has worked with numerous professional partners, including Silvia Toscano, Mora Godoy, Maria Nieves, and Guillermina Quiroga, among others. Junior studied at the New York Film Academy and in 2013 directed his first film, titled Tango and Sex.
______________________________

Guadalupe Garcia started dancing when she was 5 years old with Argentine Folklore and at 12 she started with tango. When she was 18 she got the degree of Argentinean Folk teacher. [masked] - Member of the UBALLET (Ballet de la Universidad de Buenos Aires),Mora Godoy's Tango Company, Juan Corvalán's Tangomalambo's Company, and Roberto Herrera's Company, with tours which travelled worldwide. 2012 - Korea ( World Yeosu Expo), dancer of the show in the Argentinean pavilion. 2007 - until now- works in local tango shows in Buenos Aires, such Complejo Tango, Michelangelo, Taconeando, Piazzolla Tango,Gala Tango and Tango Porteño. 2014 - Principal Dancer at the show Glorias Porteñas, partnering Juan Carlos Copes. 2015 - Tango e Paixão's Show (Brazil)

_____________________________

Rodrigo “DJ Charrua” Saraibe, originally from Uruguay, studied sound and light engineering at the University of Buenos Aires (UBA) in Argentina. Rodrigo has been working as a sound engineer, DJ, and stage manager since 1995, and has ample experience as a promoter of rock and Tango events and stage in Buenos Aires. He also worked in Miami for various local bands and TV shows as a music designer. 

As a native Uruguayan, Rodrigo began discovering his origins by exploring tango music. His passion for Tango music has lead him to acquire an extensively impressive collection of music. He has been DJ in some of the most prominent Tango Millongas in the US

Rodrigo has resided in Chicago since 2002 where he has been working in the integration of audio and visual arts using his sound and light design skills.

http://www.dancetango.com and

http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=26590514004

results.description:
Every Friday we have a causal gathering of open minded souls, who want to learn from Bhagavad Gita, the Vedic wisdom, and incorporate in to their life. We will be learning various fascinating topics like karma and reincarnation, Who am I, What is the real purpose of life? Who god is? material life, Consciousness, etc.
Mantra meditation is the process of bhakti yoga consisting of hearing and chanting the names of the lord on the beads, followed by melodious music to invoke lord's mercy. This practice has a powerful heart opening effect, which can be best understood through direct experience.
Come, relax in a warm and friendly atmosphere. Listen/observe or just chant with us or sing your heart out! Questions, personal realization, and discussion about the application of spiritual practice are welcome. 
Free Home made vegetarian/vegan dinner (prasadam) served

Admission to each meetup is free. Donations for meetups expenses are welcome.

results.description:
GENERAL DIS-ASSEMBLY NIGHT

Once a month we are putting together a night of pure DESTRUCTION!!!!! (Evil laugh).  The goal is simple, grab a item off the surplus shelf, strip it bare of all salvageable parts (screws, nuts, bolts, springs, clamps, motors, sensors, circuit boards, etc.) and discard the remains.   We are looking to increase our parts inventory while also decreasing our surplus.  It's a great opportunity to pear inside the magic of electronic's and learn about different components.  Join us tonight for pure DESTRUCTION at its best. Free and open to the public.

WARNING: Plan ahead, wear comfortable clothes that you don't mind getting messy, and be prepared to get dirty!

OPEN CRAFT NIGHT Continues:

Come make stuff! Bring a project in any state, an idea, or just  come to hang out with us while we work on projects, spontaneous brainstorms are on the forecast.

This event is free and open to the public.   

[PLEASE NOTE: All minors must be accompanied by parent and or guardian.] 

MakerBar is a 501(c)3 NJ Non-Profit Organization.. All donations are tax deductible.....consider donating today...Help keep the H@ck3ry alive! 

Interested in membership? Speak to one of our members about the many benefits of membership as well as the outstanding community that is Hoboken's MakerBar. Hudson County's one and only Hackerspace.  

http://www.makerbar.com

twitter: @MakerBar

facebook: http://www.facebook.com/TheMakerBar

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no 

displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP ,  24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
What to Expect.
Relax. It's Easy.

 

Classes are led by experts, many with thousands of hours of experience and deep knowledge and skill. In addition, there are often people training to become instructors who are happy to offer individual guidance.

 

Classes are tailored to the needs of the attendees. A starter session will be given if there are newcomers. New techniques and insights are always available for regulars. Advanced techniques may also be explored.

 

Classes begin with a brief announcement and introduction followed by 30-40 minutes of instruction and practice. Typically, classes are no more than an hour. Not long, considering the benefits can last a life time.

results.description:
Gotham Atheists weekly Drinking With Atheists Friday Night Socials!

Join us for a great night of conversation in relaxed company in New York City. We go from 8pm to around 11pm or so.

Every week we go to someone's apt, park, or bar.

Every Friday Night for 8 years we have gathered to enjoy the evening and the company of each other. DWA (Drinking With Atheists) is for Atheists, agnostics, Skeptics, Philosophers, Humanists, Freethinkers, Brights, secularists, inquiring minds, and all around nice people. No agenda but good light conversations. Great chance to meet new people and make new friends.

See you Friday Night.

Lee

we've reserved the entire bar for an afterparty!

We have two beginner swing dancing classes for you to choose from: Class 1: 6 count basics, Class2: Charleston & Balboa. First hour will be the lesson and then we will dance and socialize for half an hour.

This is a monthly series consisting of 4 classes.  We will meet every Friday (except for Sept 4).  Dates are Sept 18, 25 and Oct 2nd and 9th.  Although drop ins are welcome every week, we highly recommend to take all 4 classes so that you will be comfortable executing new moves on the social dance floor!

Join us for Steampunk Fashion Drawingat The National Arts Club! 


This photo is from the website Steampunk District. You can learn a lot about the style there. 

This session is open to sketchers of all levels from beginners to pros!


We will have two models to draw from. Watercolor and (non smelly) markers are welcome. 

This is a great chance to meet others in our group, hang out in an amazing environment (see below), listen to a wonderful DJ and of course create great work! There will also be a bar where you can buy a drink.

We will drawing in the Grand Gallery at The National Arts club one of the most historic and iconic arts buildings in New York City. (the room seen here.)

Bring your own drawing supplies, (no paint or sprays please.)


If you have any questions please feel free to email me. 


Thank you.

Simon

Everyone is waiting for their 15 minutes of fame, or was. Now that is too goddamn long. This week come to Bitches' Brew and watch some talented comedic artists before they transmute into a puff of smoke, because now they are hot. Bring your whole impatient posse or potluck dinner. results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no 

displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP ,  24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

I'll repeat the Google Wallet instructions for those unaccustomed: ***In the notes section of the payment, please leave your name and what event you are paying for! Thanks
-Download the Google Wallet app on your phone. You'll have to have a gmail account to register your username with this service if you don't already have gmail (in that case create a gmail account first... I did the same thing awhile back just to use this service)

- Create a 4 digit PIN to sign into Google Wallet. Then you'll be on the app homepage. -The left button says 'send money'. Click it and you'll have a screen where you can input a name or email address. My email address for this is [masked] .

-Once you input my username you'll see the screen where you type in the dollar amount. Once done, click the gray 'next', then the blue 'review' button in the upper right corner. -This takes to a confirmation screen. If anything looks off just click the left button on the upper lefthand side to go back a page. Otherwise, you confirm it and click send. Done! An icon will appear in your notifications area letting you know it's sent to me.

From now on, every event will not require a payment to rsvp on this page, I will check the rsvps daily to make sure everyone followed up - any issues message me on here and we will figure it out. Please work with me and send the payment when you register for the event... after this first set up it will take ten seconds each week. If you register and don't pay within 24 hours i'll reach out to you and then have to open the spot back up.. work with me here please, that would not be fun

PMJAMNITES
----------------------

is an event held every 2ND & LAST FRIDAY of the month to attract & showcase local talent and create an artistically social event. Artists pre-sign up to perform and are delegated a slot to perform . Designated Artists are featured and showcased .

PMJAMNITES LIVE MUSIC  begins at 9:00 pm thru 12:00 am

For more Info / news / pics / videos Visit :- Facebook.com/PMJAMNITES

PLAYMUSICIAN

-----------------------
PlayMusician provides a platform for artists, both upcoming and established, to showcase their talent, ranging from singer /songwriters , photographers, comediens, dancers, solo artists, spoken-word/poetry, full bands and more..


We promote local artists and musicians by creating musical events with eclectic themes and showcasing them. Seasoned artists are matched with up and coming artists.

We provide a comfortable, laid back venue with the intention of being a place where people can come together and enjoy local artists, and eventually becoming a staple in the community.

An artist’s passion is what we hope to support and encourage. It’s an artist community or family that we hope to grow through our events, website, social media and personal networking.

We help local businesses such as bars/restaurants become music venues .
Playmusician has been an artist bedrock since 2010.

results.description:
Looking for something new, different and fun to try out on a Friday night? 

Join us as we gather at Vitti's Dance Studio close by in Danbury, CT to take a beginner's dance lesson!  During the lesson, we'll be rotating partners on a large floor while learning a new dance taught by a certified dancing instructor! 

The dance practice party starts at 9 pm with the beginner's dance lesson starting at 9:30 pm.  The instructor determines which dance will be shared this night. 

After which, you can choose from three large dance floors to continue dancing:  Ballroom & Latin Room; Sizzling Salsa, Merengue and Bachata Room and the Cool Hustle & West Coast Swing Room. 

Once we've conquered the lesson, we can practice, dance and laugh our way to the end of the night at 11 pm.  The cost for this dance lesson and night of fun is just $10 collected by Vitti's Dance Studio (there is no additional meetup fee).  Note, this event is open to the public as well. 

Water and soft drinks will be available for purchase.

This is a multi group event.

Vitti’s Dance Studio 
10 Precision Road, Danbury

Patricia (L.I.E.S, Opal Tapes, Spectral Sound)
Neu Balance (1080p, Vancouver, Canada)
Solpara (Booma Collective, Other People)
Sedan Sedan Deejays

@ TBA - RSVP: [masked]
$15 presale tickets:
http://www.residentadvisor.net/event.aspx?755302

more info below:

''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
Patricia (L.I.E.S, Opal Tapes, Spectral Sound)
https://soundcloud.com/patriciaaa
http://www.mutek.org/en/montreal/2015/schedule#!programmation=artist$patricia/54
http://www.residentadvisor.net/dj/patricia-us

Neu Balance (1080p)
https://soundcloud.com/neubalance
http://www.residentadvisor.net/review-view.aspx?id=16323
http://www.mutek.org/en/montreal/2015/schedule/day_schedule#!programmation=artist$neu-balance/354

Solpara (Booma Collective)
https://soundcloud.com/solpara
http://www.mutek.org/montreal/2015/artists#!programmation=artist$solpara/334

Sedan Sedan - Deejays
https://soundcloud.com/booma-music/booma-mixtape-28-by-sedan-sedan


//


Cultivated Sound grasps you within its clutches and slowly sags you into the depths of murky bass and arctic hi-hat cuts. We have a truly massive arsenal to swim with all night long in our secret Bushwick outpost.

Patricia who guarantees to blow the back of your skull against the wall and surrounding patrons, will disturb life's balance with one of his peerless live performances. He doesn't promise to have you home by bedtime. He doesn't make those types of promises.

Taking matters into their own hands we have Neu Balance, Sam Beatch with serious issues towards your eardrums. It's nothing personal, they just don't see eye to eye. So they will blast them with their best bass and prettiest pads until the score is settled. These two are masterful and their latest on 1080p is not one to be missed, take heed.

We also have a couple hitters hitting just as heavy with Solpara doing a live set and Sedan Sedan gracing the decks with their slippery selections for your deepest desires. They haven't the slightest idea how you fell into their trap, but they're glad you did. Now they have a congregation to rough up and batter until the rooster crows and the blisters won't heal back right. They never do. It is the time to be taken hostage and ride willingly with the not so well to do who'll leave you so well done. Not one you confess to will believe you. We're not worried about you naming names or telling the tale for the simple reason that the truth is so unfathomable. If you survive, If you're left alive, we will keep a piece to snack on later...
results.name: Cultivated Sound: Techno in Bushwhick - Secret Location

results.description:
A lot of people have asked me to hold an early morning sunrise shoot.  I spent most of the summer looking at different spots inside and out of New York City. I think this is it.  The views are spectacular or you can shoot the architecture in the surrounding buildings or you can shoot the magnificent street views.  So there's a lot to offer everyone.

The meet up starts at 5:45 am.  It is still dark out at that time, but will quickly lighten up.  Sunrise is at 6:50 am. I suggest arriving a few minutes early to scout out your best vantage points.  The meet up will end at 8 am.

As usual I make suggestions and rules about my meet ups.  These are for your safety and comfort.

WHAT TO BRING:

Flashlight 

Wide Angle lens

Zoom lens

Tripod (sturdy)

Appropriate clothing

Fully charged battery

Spare Battery

Empty memory card

Patience 

A Great Attitude

IMPORTANT: If you wonder away from the group, you are effectively leaving the group/meet up.  We will not be held responsible if anything were to happen to you.  I strongly suggest you stay with the group.

BEING LATE:

The meet up starts promptly at 5:45 am.  Please make every effort to be there on time.  I suggest pairing up with another attending photographer in the event you run late.  He/she can help you catch up to the group.

BAD WEATHER:

In the event of bad weather, this meet up will be cancelled within 8 hours of it's start.  Please check the boards BEFORE leaving for this meet up. If you see that bad weather is eminent use your best judgement regarding attending this meet up.

TRAVEL:

The best way to get there is via the NJ Path Train to Hoboken from New York.   Visit: http://www.panynj.gov/path/full-schedules.html for more information.  If you are driving, make sure you have clear driving directions before you leave.

FOOD AND WATER:

As usual just about everything will be closed.  Do not rely on attaining food from that location.  Bring fresh water and snacks if needed.

*******************

Disclaimer: Participation in these events requires that you assume all risks associated with these activities, and that the Organizers, Co-Organizers and Event Hosts are in no way liable for any loss or injury as a result of your participation. In other words, you are attending these events at your own risk!! For more details, please review our rules and disclaimers.

Meetup requires a semi-annual fee to organize and maintain the group's event page.  If you would like to send a contribution to help keep NYC Photographers up and running, you can send $2.00 or more via PayPal at [masked].  This is NOT a requirement, but any amount will be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

********************

results.description:
Doing the same run we did 2 weeks back

http://www.meetup.com/jcrunners/events/224198285/


This is a great run route. The view and run on GWB is a memory and highly recommended. The bridge is about a mile long, 604 feet high, half the height of the roof of Empire State Building. 


From Grove Path, this can be as short as 14 miles (cut off immediately after going over the bridge to take the subway down to the PATH and then across) or longer to Central Park etc in New York City. 


We plan to run up the waterfront, past Hoboken, Weehawken, Edgewater, Fort Lee, over the GWB, Fort Washington Ave, down the Riverside Drive and Hudson Waterfront. 

Below is the tentative map as a guide, although we will have some detours. Last time we could not find the waterfront from 156 st as many stairs were blocked due to construction. Some of us ran Riverside Ave to 132 St, walked down the stairs and across to the waterfront. I have updated this map in that fashion.

http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/fullscreen/867678207/


Some of us plan to run after the bridge and do up till 20 miles. This route finishes at 72nd St. You may stop a little earlier near the restroom/ dirt race track where weather permitting, you will see lots of kids/ parents playing. Then take the stairs or path up to 72nd st. Subway stop for Trains 1, 2 & 3 is 2.5 blocks away.

People who want to run shorter distance.

If you meet us outside Port Imperial Ferry Terminal at 8:10 am, you can cut down 7 miles of GWB distance from Grove Path. Port Imperial to across GWB is approx 7 miles.

You can take the light rail to Port Imperial.

http://www.njtransit.com/pdf/LightRail/sf_lr_hblr_map.pdf

Last time we runners joined from PierA & 14th St Hoboken too. 

Estimated time Group is passing Port Imperial (7miles from grove)- 8:10 am

Pier A Hoboken (2.5 miles)- 7:24

14th Street waterfront Hoboken (4 miles away)- 7:40

Do write a comment if you will be there. 

You may message me on the meetup. You may send me your cell phone number and I shall send you my cell phone number, if in case we need to contact by phone to meet at Port Imperial Ferry Terminal or Hoboken stops.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet under the clock at the Grove Street PATH Station entrance

Be flexible with the schedule. We hike when we need to, or wander around to shoot as our hearts desire. If you want to do your own hike, you are also welcome to join/meet us on some parts. Rain, sleet, snow (sorry - snow can get the best of us sometime) or shine, FIDO in Prospect Park sets up a table full of goodies on the first Saturday of every month.  Look for coffee, pastries, dog biscuits as well as relevant information pertaining to off-leash activities and issues. results.description:
Welcome to Early Bird English, the fun and interesting way to improve your conversation skills early in the day -- without cutting into the rest of your weekend!  PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS MEETUP WILL BE STARTING A HALF-HOUR LATER, AT 7:30, TO BETTER ACCOMMODATE OUR MEMBERS!


Leader Eve will supply plenty to discuss, but feel free to bring along an English-language passage that you have enjoyed or found puzzling. We'll all take a look and discuss what it means.

 Early Bird English is founded on the idea that people learn best when they are enjoying themselves. Each session is quickly paced, friendly, and meant to challenge.

Eve charges a small, non-refundable fee for each session, which helps to cover the cost of the website as well as her preparation.   Please note that the $10 fee DOES NOT cover the cost of coffee! 

http://thejoyofenglish.org/

When we learn with pleasure, we never forget.

-- Alfred Mercier

"Lenovo is one of a growing number of multinationals from the non-Anglophone world that have made English their official language."

-- The Economist, 2/15/14

"A strong vocabulary may be your ticket to side-stepping dementia," says a new study from researchers in Spain.  "...An ample vocab is an indication of robust cognitive reserves, a surplus of neurons that help the brain compensate for memory lapses..." 

-- Prevention, April 2015

"It might have been easier to learn a language years ago, but still, I'm having fun...I was heartened to see, just a month or so ago, a Penn State study suggesting that learning a new language can improve your brain function.  It can, in the researcher's words, 'lead to more graceful aging.'" 

-- Tina Hay, editor, The Penn Stater, March/April 2015

"The average American speaks one language.  Be more than average."

-- magazine ad for Rosetta Stone
results.name: Let's talk!

results.description:
Tandem Hang Gliding

We are returning to have tandem hang gliding with Hangar 3 one more time. We have been to Hangar 3 each of last two years and it was certainly a blast! Also, it will be peak foliage season at the area.


Hang gliding is an air sport in which a pilot flies a light and unmotorized foot-launchable aircraft called a hang glider (also known as Delta plane or Deltaplane). Most modern hang gliders are made of an aluminium alloy or composite-framed fabric wing. The pilot is ensconced in a harness suspended from the airframe, and exercises control by shifting body weight in opposition to a control frame, but other devices, including modern aircraft flight control systems, may be used. In the sport's early days, pilots were restricted to gliding down small hills on low-performance hang gliders. However, modern technology gives pilots the ability to soar for hours, gain thousands of feet of altitude in thermal updrafts, perform aerobatics, and glide cross-country for hundreds of miles. The Fédération Aéronautique Internationale and national airspace governing organizations control some aspects of hang gliding. Learn more here...

The morning will start with a safety briefing and instruction, and you will be towed in a tandem hang glider to 2,500 ft above ground with an 'USPHA' rated tandem instructor at your side, then release to fly freely like a bird and land safely on wheels.

They video each flight with an on board camera. (Video costs additional $40)

For more info about hang gliding, click the link to Hangar 3


Depart Date: October 10th Saturday; Please arrive 15 minutes earlier.

Depart 7:30 AM: (Sheraton LaGuardia East Hotel)[masked]th Ave, Flushing, NY 11354 (Map)

Depart 8:00 AM: (Garden City Deli) Northwest corner of West 43rd St. & 9th Ave, New York, NY 10036 (Map)

Return: Depart around 2:30 PM & expect to be back in NYC at 4:00 PM and Flushing at 4:45 PM

Cost (Tandem Hang Gliding): Early Birds $209 with $79 deposit (includes BBQ cook out & transportation) for first 7 spots or 21 days in advance; Afterward, Regular $229 with $99 deposit; Bring balance of $130 cash on the event date. Video CD costs $40 additional. Bring $5 cash tips for the instructor.

Buy Ticket Here: http://oct2015tandemgliding.eventbrite.com/ You can also Chase Quickpay me at [masked] to avoid transaction fee. (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) When Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location. Your spot is NOT confirmed until your payment is received.

Weight:[masked]lbs

Items to Bring: Comfortable cloth, sun-glass, sun screen, & camera

Amenities: Picnic tables, swing set, large chess set, and lots of fresh air

FREE BBQ: Hamburgers, grilled chicken, hot dogs, bottled water, and Gatorade. 

Included: Certified guides, tandem hang gliding, instruction, FREE BBQ, & luxury round trip MB Sprinter transportation from NYC.


Maximum: 15

Refund Policy:

* $20 processing fee if cancelled 3 weeks prior to the event date;
* Refund 50% of event fee if cancelled 10 days prior to the event date;
* Afterward, no refund for cancellation or no show; however, spots can be transferred to your friends with $20 processing fee.


Note: There are waiting time between turns, so feel free to bring somethings you can do during off time. Suggestions: volleyball, frisbee, cards and board games.

My First Tandem Hang Gliding Video:


http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bbv_A9TIW7A

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bbv_A9TIW7A

Pictures from previous tandem hang gliding events

2011: http://www.meetup.com/NYCAYS/photos/2106231/
2012: http://www.meetup.com/NYCAYS/photos/9395892/
2013: http://www.meetup.com/NYCAYS/photos/15573582/
2014: http://www.meetup.com/NYCAYS/photos/22858152/

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Just in case anyone needs a refresher, some guidance from Coach Ted Lasso.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6KeG_i8CWE8

No refunds or credits will be offered. Please be 100% sure that you can attend before you RSVP.

Please have a fun, positive, and supportive attitude. Pass the ball to your teammates and have a good time. NO rough playing, slide tackling, or screaming at others will be tolerated. You'll be removed from the game immediately.

No cleats are allowed. Let's do our part to preserve the field. Turf or running shoes are recommended.

Always bring a *dark and white* t-shirt

Be on time.

Teams are broken out ahead of each game based on skill level. Beginner, intermediate, and advanced players are all encouraged to join.

We play THREE, 25-30 minute games with a brief break between each game.

results.description:
Get ready for another NYC Code Camp, to be held at the Microsoft Offices in midtown Manhattan! This is an all-day event with refreshments served, including breakfast, lunch, and beverages throughout the day.

Registration is now open. Registration will be processed through Eventbrite at http://codecampnyc.eventbrite.com and attendance costs a mere $10 for the entire day’s worth of content (less than the cost of two lattes at Starbucks)!

Code Camps are "grass roots" mini application platform developer conferences featuring presentations by developers and for developers. The event is open to attendees and presenters of all stripes and experience!

This event is being supported by Microsoft and other corporate sponsors but is driven by the community: user group activists, developer "influentials", and enthusiastic volunteers.

NYC Code Camp will feature sessions on a wide range of technologies and topics, including .NET, JavaScript, Angular, Azure, Windows 10, mobile development, ASP.NET, Visual Studio, TFS, Web Design, IoT, Typescript, Git, NoSQL, Xamarin, F#, Agile, Security, Firebase and much more. For a complete list of the selected sessions, see the interactive session listing here.

We look forward to seeing you at what is shaping up to be another stellar Code Camp event!

YOU MUST REGISTER ON EVENTBRITE: http://codecampnyc.eventbrite.com. A Simple RSVP on Meetup is NOT enough to secure your spot and the event is expected to sell out.
results.how_to_find_us: YOU MUST REGISTER ON EVENTBRITE: http://codecampnyc.eventbrite.com.

results.description:
When people hear about meditation, they almost always say that they have either never tried it or they were not able to do it. You may have expected that thoughts were supposed to go away, but when you closed your eyes, more thoughts than ever came up.

We invite you to come and experience how meditation can happen effortlessly with a little attention to our very own breath! The free session will include light yoga, breathing techniques and relaxing meditation and will be led by one of the volunteers of the Art of Living foundation.

 

Art of Living Secaucus Center
Email: <a>[masked]</a>
Phone: <a>[masked]</a>
Meetup: <a>http://www.meetup.com/Lets-Meditate-Secaucus/</a>;
Twitter: https://twitter.com/#secaucusaol
Web: http://www.artofliving.org/us-en/secaucus

results.description:
COME JOIN US FOR A FUN-FILLED DAY IN THE ADIRONDACKS!

This meetup is posted as an option for attendees of Glenn's Adirondacks Fall Foliage - Columbus Day Weekend but is also open to anyone who wishes to attend!

Our plan pending good weather will be to start at the Atmospheric Scientific Research Center (ASRC), hike out and back to Esther Peak and then on to the Whiteface summit. There is a tower at the summit with spectacular views and options to buy lunch. From there the group can proceed back the way we came or continue along the full traverse via Whiteface Landing to Connery Pond.  It will be a longer day for anyone choosing to complete the Traverse and the group will be expected to move at a decent pace of at least 1 mph uphill and 2 mph on level or downhill terrain.

The views from Whiteface encompass all sides and include the Green Mountains of Vermont, the skyscrapers in Montreal on a very clear day, and the White Mountains of New Hampshire on an even clearer day.

This Adirondack 46 High Peak is number 5 on the list.

Whiteface is often times climbed with Esther Mountain.

Whiteface Mountain is a unique Mountain in that it has a perfectly good access road to just below the summit. Then a short walk through a manmade passage, within the mountain, will bring you to an elevator which will deliver you to the visitor's area near the summit. But, if you want to climb it, you will need to use one of these routes below. Whiteface also has numerous slides on its slopes which would offer excellent bushwhacking and exploring options. Slides however are very dangerous and should only be done by experienced, fit hikers.

You may have heard a bit about the Whiteface Ski Center, it's world renowned and still used to this day for world class competition. The ski slopes are not a route to the summit, they end quite a ways from the summit, and it is not recommended.

Primary Trailhead: From the intersection of Route 73 and Route 86, follow Route 86 toward Wilmington. Continue into Wilmington to the four-way stop sign. Take a left onto Route 431 (Whiteface Mountain Road). Follow here for 2.4 miles to the Atmospheric Science Research Center Road on the left. Follow this road around the one-way roundabout to the trail on the right, just past a dirt road that descends into the woods. The trail is not labeled with a DEC sign.

This is a 3.9 mile hike, one way. From the trailhead you descend a bit to a very long and steep climb up Marble Mountain. The Marble Mountain section used to be an old ski slope and you will be able to see that one way – old cement footers still line the trail.

From the top of Marble Mountain you will come to an intersection, left is the secondary trail outlined below. Right is the route you will want. After a short break on a flatter section you will start a demanding climb through an evergreen forest that opens up a few views along the way. After about 1.5 miles you will come to a rather large cairn at a trail intersection. This is the herd-path to Esther Mountain. Continuing straight the climb relaxes a bit after a short descent before it climbs steeply to the Whiteface Memorial Highway – trail four outlined below. During times where the road is open to vehicles it cannot be walked on. The trail leaves the roadside as soon as it hits it and climbs steeply up to an open ridge with amazing views. You will continue the ridge to the summit of Whiteface where you will be greeted in awe by all those who drove up.

8-12 miles RT, depending on route, challenging climb for experienced hikers, Elevation: 4867', Ascent: 2535'

http://www.lakeplacid.com/do/hiking/whiteface-mountain


WE WILL MEET at the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC) 110 Marble Mt Rd. Wilmington, NY

[masked], [masked]

TO COMPLETE THE TRAVERSE I WILL NEED A VOLUNTEER WITH A CAR TO MEET BY 7:30AM AT  the Connery Pond Rd access off Rt 86

[masked], [masked]


Distance: Up to 12 miles

Hiking Pace: up to 2.0 mph

Estimated Hike Time: 9-10 hours

Difficulty: Intermediate - Rocky Terrain, steep Ascents and Descents

Current Weather Forecast:  Cloudy with a high of 46 degrees

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• Gaiters

• A Backpack - with Raincoat/Windbreaker, Warm Layers, Hat & Gloves

• Hiking Poles

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, Lunch, First Aid, Headlamp, Sun Protection, etc.

RELATED MAPS:

Adirondack Park - Saranac/Paul Smiths Trail Map #746

WHERE TO STAY?

I will be driving up early Friday and staying through Monday with Glenn as part of the HOAGies Adirondacks Fall Foliage - Columbus Day Weekend. Glenn has some spots left in a rented house if interested. Contact him through his meetup if interested in sharing lodging.


Other options in the area include the following:

I usually stay at the Lodge below as its close to LOJ and Lake Placid and the staff are really friendly:

Website: http://www.schulteslodge.com/

or you also might want to check out:

Adirondack Hiking maximum group size limitations:

• A group size limit of 15 people for day hiking is in place. Any group larger than 15 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.


NYC HIKING & OUTDOOR ADVENTURE GROUP LEGAL DISCLAIMER
Waiver of liability

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

The NYC Hiking & Outdoor Adventure Group does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers.

This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. results.description:
After hiking this, I have to warn you that it is only for very fit and experienced hikers who aren't too afraid of heights. I am postponing it for two reasons: hopefully we will be able to enjoy fall colors in October, and I need more time to recover from hiking it!

There is a short 2.5-mile loop and at least one other point where you can turn back if you don't want to do the whole hike once you've started it, but be forewarned that this hike is around 10 miles long, and if you are taking the train back from Beacon, you have an additional 1.5 miles of city walking afterward. With frequent breaks including 20 minutes for lunch, we completed the hike in 5.5 hours, but it was difficult. The initial climb takes you up 1200 feet or so, and since the ridge is not level, you end up approaching 3000 feet of elevation changes.

You can get a sense of the difficulty of the hike from the first photo above. MOST of the first 90 minutes is scrambling up steep rock faces as pictured. And frequently you need to climb up and down similar faces after that. And though none of the climbs are dangerous (the ledges are usually good sized), if you are not a careful climber, you could risk falling. And if you are afraid of heights (and I am) you will want to stay focused on where you are climbing, not turning around until you are on a sturdy ledge. And there are alternate routes on the steeper faces that take longer but ascend slower.


Because we get pretty high up, and the views are often amazing.

There is a fire tower near the end of the hike that has amazing views, but you can see all the way back to Manhattan even before you go that high up.

For those taking the train:  There are only two Metro North trains that stop at the trailhead, and we will plan to take the second one at 8:40 a.m. To make sure everyone has tickets and gets to the platform in time, we will meet at the GCT Info Booth at 8:15. There is a $6 per ticket discount if you buy your ticket online before you arrive at Grand Central. You will want one ticket Grand Central to Breakneck Ridge, and one Beacon to Grand Central. (If you end up changing your mind and taking a loop back to the origin trailhead, you can still use it for one of the two afternoon return trains at 4:13 or 7:17 p.m.) You need to be on the last car of the train to disembark, since it is just a whistlestop, not a station.


For those driving: Since we are starting and ending at different trailheads, drivers should plan to meet at the Casino trailhead parking lot (see map) in Beacon. From there some of the cars can take hikers to the Breakneck Ridge parking areas, and then pick up cars there after the hike. I would recommend meeting at 9:45 a.m. so everyone has time to coordinate and get to the other trailhead by the time the train arrives around 10:15 a.m. Both parking lots are just off Route 9D.

More than many hikes, you will want really good soles on your shoe, with good traction, thickness for hiking on rocks, and ideally hard toes to soften the blow of much potential stubbing. Though the ridge is fairly dry (we only cross one stream), you may want to pack bug spray. And because we're talking five hours of constant cardio workout, you will want a lot of water with you -- we decided a minimum of 1.5 liters was required. And when we get to the first summit, we will have lunch, and you will likely want snacks for other breaks. And much of the trail is in sunlight, so you definitely need sunscreen.


If you need a rest at any point, but especially on the way up in the first 90 minutes, TAKE IT. There is no reason to force yourself to keep going when you're panting and exhausted. Try to make sure someone is within sight when you rest, so you don't get left behind. The trail is pretty well marked, but there are a lot of dead ends and washes that look like trails that will lead you astray.


Thanks to Mike, John, Richard, and Joseph for helping with the test hike.


For a trail map:  http://www.nysparks.com/parks/attachments/HudsonHighlandsNORTHHudsonHighlandsStateParkTrailMap.pdf


For a video orientation:  https://youtu.be/83pJynYfjLU

results.description:
~8, 13-mile options RT. Start at Bear Mt Inn, hike or run hilly red-blue-yellow trails and back! At Bear Mountain State Park. Exploratory adventure trek: Work together to use maps to route-find.  

DETAILS

Meet: In front of inn, (845)[masked] . Restrooms and water fountains inside by gift shop.


Transport: 

At this meeting time, the only way to get there is for you to drive. Cars: $8 /vehicle. If people want to drive to and volunteer as drivers, please say so in comments section below. Members can carpool and split the cost of car admission and gas. 

How:  Social. Partner / form pace groups. (Co-host Rosanna will run/walk as sweeper (combo: run slowly and fast hike). Feel free to go ahead at your own pace -- just make sure you have your running buddy, and  map as a guide! 


Rain or shine. Heavy rain cancels! Check comments section for updates.

Who:  Trail runners and hikers. All paces are welcome!  Guests, friends and family are welcome. Each person is expected to be prepared, self-sufficient, able to find her way back to start, and able to help each other if necessary. Thanks.

Groups:  Each group/partner will wait for each other at intersections, leaving no one behind. This is a good opportunity to work as a team with other local hikers/runners at your level, test map-reading skills, and to discover trails without having to do it on your own.

REQUIREMENTS

BRING

1) Download/print and carry:  
a)  "Harriman Bear Mountain" trails map (map #119)

b) http://files.meetup.com/18274717/Bear_mountainSP_Blue-yellow_8-13mi.pdf  Turn sheet for options: ~13 miles:  lollipop-shaped route  

or ~8 miles loop.

2)  Backpack water and fuel! None on route!  


**  Optional: You can buy the paper map at the gift shop. If closed, go to parks police station across the field. It's also available at REI. 



Facilities:  Restrooms and water fountains at start (and off-route at Anthony Wayne Rec area)

Weather:  Bear Mountain, NY

Comments? Want to form a carpool? Post in comments section below.

Happy trails!


_____________________________________________________


Note

This is not an organized training program. It is just a notice of activities some members are planning to do that is sent out to those who might want to join them. By choosing to join them, you agree that you are an adult over 21 and agree to the legal disclaimer. Each person is solely responsible for himself, and for following trail etiquette<a href="http://www.trailrunner.com/news/trail_etiquette.htm"></a>, laws, park rules, and park safety guidelines. Thanks!!!

Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
Hello! Now this is for those who feel adventurous -

I rented a Private Boat for Our Journey, It  will take us to the Mysterious Island Haunted Island of Banneman Castle

We have the Ghost Tour of th  island "Legends"

http://www.bannermancastle.org/island-history.html


 On Saturday, Oct 10 th, 2015 

Departing: 8:30am FROM WHOLE FOODS BERGEN MALL 

  Here is the Haunted-tour- Info
http://www.hudsonvalleyhalloweenmagazine.com/haunted-hudson-valley/bannermansisland


The island is still as primitive as it was in the early 1900's, No electricity, No running water....Haunted ?  Hopefully ! 


We take a short boat ride over to the island . Upon reaching the island we will be greeted by your tour guides and will be given an escorted tour of the rugged little island. Our tour will include history of the island and plenty of opportunities for photographs. The tour will take approximately one and one half hours ( 2-1/2 hrs).

This island is a tiny jewel in the setting of the Hudson . This island is like Shuttle ISLAND island - Only way on ....or off is a boat. 

Once an uninhabited place, accessible only by boat, it was considered haunted by some Indian tribes and thus became a refuge for those trying to escape them. These superstitions promoted by later Dutch sailors make for many fanciful tales.  

Itinerary: Saturday, Oct 10th

8:30 am Departing  Whole Foods Paramus

</a>Bergen Town Center, 300 Bergen Town Center, Paramus, NJ 07652

<a href="https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=2&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0CCMQFjABahUKEwiWl8yu9qzIAhVGaT4KHTc0BaE&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wholefoodsmarket.com%2Fstores%2Fparamus&usg=AFQjCNEGWEJw3l0ascORltwau6ObaT0s1g&sig2=jUnHxOQ2exk8GoI-q0iQ5g&bvm=bv.104317490,d.cWw">Paramus | Whole Foods Market

1. Our First Stop is The Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site Hyde Park Contains Springwood", the lifelong home of America's only 4-term President. 

After The Tour

2.  Lunch in New Paltz  

3. Private Boat charted for the Tour of the Island. 

After the tour of Banner-man Island.

We will Travel back to Maywood , Inn  for a

 Delicious Dinner  Buffet  

Tips, Tax, Tours -


Everything included for this Adventure 

Price $129.00 For Everything! 


The Boat only Hold 44 People. So that's it!

Robert Gilligan- PO BOX 184, RIDGE WOOD,NJ 07451

or PayPal to [masked]

Thanks, Robert

Details:

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.)  Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances.  We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation:

We'll play rain or shine.  We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
New York Italians have been asked again to participate in a City Harvest volunteer project to take place on Saturday, October 10th in the Bronx! 

The project will take place at St. Mary's Park Mobile Market, 595 Trinity Avenue, Bronx, NY. The site is easily accessible by the 6 train to E. 149th Street (5 block walk) or the 2/5 trains to Jackson Avenue (one block walk).

Volunteers will be stationed at 3-4 market tables, each supplied with thousands of pounds of fresh produce that they will help distribute to eligible market-goers. Sample produce items may include bananas, onions, cabbage, or potatoes. As the market-goers stop by each table, volunteers greet them and then weigh and bag the produce. Note: All food is distributed free of charge.

All volunteers should arrive promptly at 8:45am. Your promptness ensures that we will be able to start the Mobile Market on time. The market should end around 12pm.

If you sign up for this event, you are obligated to attend.  City Harvest relies heavily on their volunteers, so please do not commit without intention to fulfill.


You MUST sign up using this link, which will redirect you to the City Harvest page:


https://cityharvestvolunteers.civicore.com/index.php?section=indGpRegistrations&action=profile_conditional&fwID=3782


You will be able to register until Friday, October 9th. After that date, sign up will be closed.  

Volunteers are essential to helping City Harvest end hunger in New York City and we couldn't do it without you! If you have any questions, please direct them to [masked] and we will respond promptly.

results.description:
This is a moderately paced adventure under, over, around and through many of the amazing architectural wonders throughout Central Park. We begin our walk at the southwest tip of Central Park South and zigzag our way up the eastern half of Central Park to The Harlem Meer at 110th St. Then we circle back along the western half of the park and finish at Sheep's Meadow. Please bring water and lunch or snack for this fascinating 5-hour journey of approx. 8 miles. 

MEET: 9 AM sharp at the Atrium entrance to the Time Warner Towers Complex at 59th St. & Columbus Circle. Take the A, D or 1 train to 59th St. Rain or Shine! 

Leader: Matthew Brozyna [masked]

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for Shorewalkers members who have paid the $20 annual membership fee, $3 for non-members. Non-members please pay the hike leader at the beginning of the hike or visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.

You’ll walk away from this class with cloth napkins made by you and lots of practical knowledge!

results.description:
Cosmism was originated in Russia more than a hundred years ago. That was an esoteric futuristic philosophy about post-humanity, technological immortality, resurrection and cosmic expansion. Modern Cosmism bring to the original doctrine the ontological foundation, a scientific structure and a deeper comprehension of possible technology aims to create in the future a new synthetic reality where the concepts of truth, consciousness, freedom and happiness will be deeply revised.

The conference will review the critical question about a potential contact with advanced extraterrestrial  civilizations and suggest few hypotheses about their “eerie silence”. We will touch some related problems in cosmology, and astrophysics, such as the shape and future of the Universe, black hole information paradox, multidimensional space, dark energy and interpretation of quantum mechanics. Are they a separate arrow of time? Are there exceptions to the principle of causality?

Like no other area of philosophy and technology before, Modern Cosmism raises fundamental questions about the post human nature and how it will be connected to the reality. Is the structure of reality included the consciousness? Is a non biological hardware can support the consciousness? How we can define Cosmic Evolution and what is the role of intelligent life?

The conference will address important philosophical issues that arise with the design of artificial consciousness, mind uploading and cyber-immortality.  How will our concepts of subjectivity, perception, and morality change, if we will live in a virtual reality of mega-conscious environment where individuals can experience multiple presence, personality and have no gender. Will we be able to create super intelligent agents with consciousness and feelings? What are the limits of artificial capacities or functional simulations, we should create?  Could we enhance our own humanity by genetically redesign our nature?  

Our keynote and plenary speakers are well-known cosmologists, neuroscientists, philosophers, interdisciplinary researchers, international protagonists of Cosmism and Transhumanism. Their lectures will discuss the most important current issues of Modern Cosmism from the point of view of philosophy, cosmology, ethics, technology, robotics and psychology. 

http://cosmism.com/events.html

Reception after 6 pm for conference participants

Free for Meetup members 

http://cosmism.com/freeconf.html

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

Local Hack Day is an annual hackathon sponsored by Major League Hacking, Knewton and Code School where teams of diverse students from across C/I’s programs will learn, collaborate, and engage with mentors to build tech products that solve real world challenges.

This event will expose over 100 C/I students to the power of technology with workshops on topics like Git, JavaScript, Angular JS, Node.js, Rails, and APIs.

Location: The Fordham Foundry is located at 400 E. Fordham Road, 7th floor in the Bronx, close to the 4, B, D, and MetroNorth trains. The building entrance is on Webster Avenue next to the 24-Hour Fitness.

Schedule: The event runs from 9am – 8pm and the official schedule will be released in the week before the hackathon along with the DevPost for the event.

What is a Hackathon? A hackathon is an event in which teams spend time learning something new and building something awesome. Everyone from C/I is invited, from absolute beginners to our seasoned hacker alumni.

Can I be a mentor? Yes! Sign up FOR FREE by getting a “Coach/Interactive (Mentor)” ticket on Eventbrite through the link below.

http://www.weare.ci/event/local-hack-day/


Can I sponsor this hackathon? Yes! Contact Tom at [masked] for more information.

results.description:
Contact:   Mike Clancy  [masked]

Spots are limited as the park has set a group limit.   It's 15 now but I may be able to add a couple more spots later in the week. Please be sure you can attend before signing up.


The leaves are ready to change color at the e beautiful Sam's Point area of Minnewaska State Park. The park is at the south end of the Shawangunk Ridge off State Route 52 in Cragsmoor, NY.   The Visitor's Center opens and 9AM.  Parking fee is $10/car.  There is some great information/videos at the park web site:  http://www.nysparks.com/parks/193/details.aspx

On the holiday weekend the lot is expected to fill quickly so please arrive on time. We will start from the Visitor's Center and basically follow the Shawangunk Ridge Trail (SRT) to the 150+ feet Verkeerder Kill Falls where we will break for lunch. On the way to the falls, we will take a detour to explore the interesting features of the Ice Caves. 

Start time:  9:15 AM                     Duration: Approx 5 hrs

Distance:  Approx. 7 miles         Difficulty:  Moderate

Elev. Gain: Approx 600'

Gear:  proper footwear, clothing for changing temps, headlamp or light, water,               snacks/lunch

                                                         ***********

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

Our annual costs:
meetup.com: $144
domain name: $15
clincher balls: $300

results.description:
Join us for an adventure biking several Southern Rockland County Trails in Nyack. We will bike on three contiguous trails - the Joseph B. Clark Trail, the Old Erie Path and the Raymond G. Esposito Memorial Trail. After leaving the rail-trails, a short road bike along Broadway will bring us to Nyack Beach State Park where we will bike along the Hudson River just under Hook Mountain. Total biking distance will be approximately 22 miles on level gravel/dirt terrain. We will take our time exploring our surroundings - hoping for signs of fall color - consider this an all-day activity. Bring lunch, snacks, water, patch kit/extra tube and a hybrid/mountain bike. Helmet is mandatory! Meet at 9:30am SHARP at Lowe's Parking Lot in Orangeburg [there is a small section for trail users]. Optional after-hike refreshments at local eatery will be offered.


Meet at Lowe's parking lot: 206 Route 303, Orangeburg, NY 10962, there is a small area designated for those using the rail-trail.


http://activities.outdoors.org/search/index.cfm/action/details/id/85527


Photo by Sue Bickford-Martin

results.description:
This experiential workshop helps us develop nature spiritual practices so that we nurture not just ourselves, but all of nature.

Registration is now open, and required. Wainwright House in Rye is handling the registration. Click here to register.

General information follows:

Nurturing Nature:  Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earth’s


A workshop that helps us live compassionately, joyfully, and healthy in a multispecies world

As never before, humans feel disconnected from nature and the beings that co-inhabit the earth with us.  We strongly desire to care for other species and ecosystems, and are unsure how we can maximize flourishing for individuals of all species, as well as for ourselves.  One key to the many living well is to remember that we exist in an interdependent web where all beings are connected to each other in inherent worth, dignity and beauty. 

This Nurture Nature Workshop...

-Seeks to remedy that situation by inviting participants to a lifelong discovery of nature accompanied by practice and discipline that that will provide resources and resilience for living compassionately.  By accepting our own inner animal, our compassion spreads outrageously beyond kin and kind to all of life. 

-Builds community and fosters relationships through slowing down, sharing experiences, and co-designing activities that nourish us and all of nature.

- Offers learning, practice, and discussion involving concrete foundations that clear the way for us to nurture ourselves, others, and the earth.  These foundations draw on science, psychology, communication theory and practices, and various spiritual and religious approaches such as Albert Schweitzer’s Reverence for Life ethic and a variety of mindfulness practices. 

- Engages and stimulates us through activities, such as music videos, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussion and exercises, games, meditation, role-plays, and nature experiences.

The facilitator, Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, offers to you her skills gained from a lifetime of working with animals as a wildlife veterinarian, and from her experience and training as a Certified Trainer in Nonviolent Communication and a Unitarian Universalist minister.  She has devoted her life to addressing the health of humans and nonhumans together, knowing that the health of our biotic communities depends on holding as precious the needs and well-being of all individuals of all species.  Currently she serves life as the Director of One Earth Conservation and Ministry, facilitating learning and practice communities such as this workshop and also collaborating on multiple teams throughout Latin America that seek to heal our biotic communities through incorporating the human dimension in parrot conservation.

results.description:
LEADER:  Debbie Bell ([masked] or <a>[masked]</a> (NCA 9 PM))

RATING:  C 5 C

Meet at Iona Island parking area on Rt. 9W, south of Bear Mountain Inn, at 9:30 AM.  We will walk on old carriage trails and country lanes in historic Doodletown.  Doodletown was first occupied by French Huguenot settlers in the 1700s, and at one time boasted 350 residents.  It was acquired by the Palisades Park Commission in the 1900s and, as the occupants left, or were removed by eminent domain, the buildings were destroyed.  Today we see only foundations and signs.  The terrain has some ups and downs, but we will go at a leisurely pace.  All hikers who want a relaxed day in the woods are welcome.  Please wear appropriate footwear for unpaved trails, and bring lunch and water.  Register with the leader (above) in case there are last-minute changes because of weather or other developments.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

Paul

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Paul
